Award.AwardTitle: Divergence of novel, parallel, and speciation traits: the mechanisms and consequences of yellow monkeyflower adaptation to extreme geothermal habitats
Award.AbstractNarration:
How do plants adapt to cope with extreme environments? What are the long- and short-term consequences of that adaptation? Understanding the genetic and physiological mechanisms that let a few plant species thrive in unusual, otherwise barren, habitats is both a fundamental scientific puzzle and a key to mitigating the effects of environmental change. This research investigates adaptation in the yellow monkeyflower, one of a handful of plants living in the extraordinarily hot soils of thermal areas in Yellowstone National Park. Using new genomics approaches, it will determine the genes underlying unique (e.g., heat tolerance) and repeatedly evolving traits, and ask how they contribute to survival, reproduction, and the development of new species. All focal traits are of agricultural interest, so this project may reveal stress-tolerance mechanisms transferable to crops, while also answering fundamental evolutionary questions. The project will train Montana students in cutting-edge genomics techniques and, through National Park-based outreach efforts, communicate the multiple values of natural diversity.

The primary goals of the project are to identify genomic regions contributing to divergence in nine focal traits and to determine how they contribute to both local adaptation and species barriers. This will reveal: a) how plants cope with extreme environments; b) whether that imposes tradeoffs in performance under more benign conditions; c) which genetic pathways are used repeatedly during adaptation; and d) what are the key steps in the formation of new species. The research plan combines genetic mapping, physiological assays, and field surveys with whole-genome scans at multiple spatial scales.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report

 

This project investigated mechanisms of adaptation and speciation in model flowering plants known as monkeyflowers, which are remarkable diverse and genetically tractable.  Key scientific outcomes include the identification of a simple genetic switch that transforms plants from perennials (living multiple years) to annuals (living only a single year), allowing them to thrive in extreme geothermal soils in Yellowstone National Park. Unlike similar transitions in other monkeyflowers, this switch involves only a small number of genes and does not cause theoretically predicted tradeoffs between vegetative growth and flower or seed production. Similar life history transitions are central to crop domestication but have not previously been genetically dissected in any system. The NSF-funded research on plants from the extreme Yellowstone habitats has also identified novel sets of genes (loci) causing radical shifts in flowering time, the ability to make abundant seeds without need for pollinators, leaf anatomy and carbohydrate allocation, as well as genes contributing to survival in harsh soils and pollen viability. Understanding all of these trait reveals how plants cope with extreme environments, with important fundamental and applied implications.

 

Beyond providing insight into multiple axes of plant adaptation, the funded research challenged prevalent ideas about the role of adaptation in speciation. Many of the traits studied in Yellowstone (flowering time, selfing ability) not only confer adaptation to alternative habitats, but act as barriers to gene flow, generating ideal conditions for  sympatric speciation by natural selection. Nonetheless monkeyflowers only show signs of speciation (genome-wide differentiation) at one site, where a 200m gap in habitat completely isolates an extreme geothermal population. This research argues that, even with extraordinarily strong selection on just the right traits, sympatric speciation must be extremely rare; this re-emphasizes the importance of geographical context (along with adaptive divergence) for understanding speciation and diversification.

 

Other scientific outcomes supported by this grant included new insights into a) conflicts between the DNA and protein components of centromeres (which mediate faithful chromosomal segregation at every cell division) and nuclear and mitochondrial genomes, b) tradeoffs between plant growth and defense against herbivores, c) contributions of root-inhabiting fungi to local adaptation and negative ecological feedbacks, d) variation in gene number as a source of climate adaptation, e) co-ordination between leaf physiology and other plant traits, and f) the ubiquity of genetic exchange during species radiation. Further, funded researchers contributed to the development of new approaches for measuring natural selection at the level of individual DNA variants in the wild and to publicly archived genomic datasets, methods, and resources for the important model plant Mimulus.

 

The intellectual products were shared with the scientific community in >15 national and international presentations by supported personnel, as well as 6 empirical research publications (with more to come). In addition, support from the grant facilitated the writing of four major synthetic reviews clarifying how non-Mendelian transmission and genetic incompatibilities in hybrids illuminate biological phenomena from cell to community scales.

 

Potential broader impacts of the basic scientific findings range from crop improvement to climate change mitigation to tailoring gene drives to control invasive species to human disease biology. In addition, the work provides a charismatic example of extreme adaptation in America’s flagship national park, with ongoing public education spin-offs. The project contributed directly to the professional training of two postdoctoral scholars (both now permanently employed), two graduate students, two post-baccalaureate trainees, one high school student, and >10 undergraduate students (>50% female). Finally, support from the funded research contributed to the development of a shared monkeyflower community workspace, facilitating ongoing and future research and training collaborations.
